headline: CNN Newsroom
subHeadline: Former President Jimmy Carter Dead At 100; Georgia Mourning Former President Jimmy Carter. Aired 9-10p ET

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is CNN Breaking News.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: And good evening. Thanks for joining us. I'm Anderson Cooper in New York. An outpouring of sympathy from around the world as former President Jimmy Carter has died at the age of 100. The 39th President United States was surrounded by family as he died at his home in Plains, Georgia, following two years in hospice care. The American flag flying at half staff right now at the White House where President Carter held the Oval Office from 1977 to 1981. President Biden on a winter vacation, spoke earlier about his colleague and friend.(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) JOE BIDEN, USA PRESIDENT: The entire Carter family, on behalf of the world, the whole nation, we send our whole heartfelt sympathies and gratitude. Our gratitude for sharing President Carter with us for so many years. You know, Jimmy Carter stands as a model of what it means to live a life of meaning and purpose, a life of principle, faith and humility. His life dedicated to others. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: During his single term in office, Jimmy Carter forged a rare and enduring peace deal between Israel and Egypt. Formalized relations with communist China. President Nixon had begun and put human rights at the forefront of U.S. Foreign policy. But his presidential career was only four years long as voters blamed him for inflation at home and of course, the 444-day hostage crisis in Iran, which ended just one day after Carter left office.The former president spoke several years ago with CNN about what he wanted people to remember about his time in the White House. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: What would you like to be remembered in terms of your legacy for your presidency?JIMMY CARTER, 39TH U.S. PRESIDENT: Well, we always told the truth. We kept our country at peace. We brought peace to other people around the world and we promoted human rights and never deviated from that commitment. Those are some of the things of which I'm proud. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Certainly after the next four decades after the presidency, Jimmy Carter changed the world's view of what American presidents do after they leave the White House. Blazing a path forward that's become certainly a shining example of doing good for other people. And Wolf Blitzer gives us a look back at President Carter's extraordinary life and career.(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: We just want the truth again.WOLF BLITZER, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voiceover): Jimmy Carter was elected president barely two years after the lawbreaking and cover-ups of the Watergate scandal forced President Richard Nixon to resign. His candor seemed like a breath of fresh air.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: There's a fear that our best years are behind us, but I say to you that our nation's best is still ahead.BLITZER (voiceover): James Earl Carter was born on October 1, 1924. His father ran an agricultural supply store in Plains, Georgia. His mother was a nurse. He was smart enough and tough enough to receive an appointment to the U.S. Naval Academy. Just after graduation in 1946, he married Rosalind Smith. His naval career took him from battleships to the new nuclear submarine program. But when his father died in 1953, he left the military and returned to Georgia, where he spent the next two decades running the family peanut farm business and slowly and steadily beginning a political career that saw him elected governor of Georgia in 1970.

utterances.speaker: JODY POWELL, FORMER WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.sentences: To use an old 1950s term, if there ever was a classic example of an inner-directed man, you know Jimmy Carter's ed.BLITZER (voiceover): His close friend and associate was press secretary Jody Powell, who died in 2009.

utterances.speaker: POWELL
utterances.sentences: He enjoyed people and he enjoyed talking to people. I think he enjoyed those early days of campaigns when there was much more personal interaction with the voters than he did the latter stages, when it was a series of set-piece speeches and large crowds.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: My name is Jimmy Carter and I'm running for president.BLITZER (voiceover): In 1976, the former Georgia governor went from being Jimmy who to the White House. Not everyone in Washington was happy to see him.

utterances.speaker: TOM OLIPHANT, THE BOSTON GLOBE
utterances.sentences: Washington, even more than New York, is the snobbiest city in America, and Carter and the Georgians were treated like dirt, condescendingly and with hostility. If he had a fault, it was that he matched Washington's hostility with his own.BLITZER (voiceover): Early on, Carter was accused of presidential micromanaging, of excessive attention to detail.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: We must face the fact that the energy shortage is permanent.BLITZER (voiceover): During Carter's term, Americans endured a shock steady increase in oil and gasoline prices, which forced everything to cost more. To some, Carter's stark comments began to sound like moralizing.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: The erosion of our confidence in the future is threatening to destroy the social and the political fabric of America.BLITZER (voiceover): In 1980, Carter faced Republican challenger Ronald Reagan, who exuded sunny optimism and asked voters a simple question.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: Are you better off than you were four years ago?BLITZER (voiceover): Jimmy Carter lost the election, but not his resolve to make a difference. He and Rosalynn founded the Carter Center in part to promote peace, democracy, human rights, as well as economic and social development all over the world. Carter monitored elections for fairness. He went to North Korea and Cuba and met with leaders usually shunned by the U.S. including representatives of Hamas, the Palestinian organization both the U.S. And Israel have branded as terrorists.

utterances.speaker: POWELL
utterances.sentences: This is a man who has a really unique commitment to public service. It really is a calling with him.BLITZER (voiceover): In autumn of 2002, Carter was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, the culmination of an incredible career as a world leader and as a citizen.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: I'm delighted and humbled and very grateful that the Nobel Peace Prize committee has given me this recognition.BLITZER (voiceover): He still wasn't done. Carter remained active into his 90s, traveling, writing books, building Habitat for Humanity homes, and, to the discomfort of his successors, speaking out on the issues of the day. He criticized Bill Clinton's affair with Monica Lewinsky, called George W. Bush's international policy, quote, "the worst in history."

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: But from your definition, you believe the United States, under this administration, has used torture?

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: I don't. I don't think it. I know it. Certainly.BLITZER (voiceover): He also took on President Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Does America want kind of a jerk as president?

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: Apparently, from his recent elections, yes. I never knew it before.BLITZER (voiceover): Carter survived a cancer scare in 2015 and kept going.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: Didn't find any cancer at all, so.BLITZER (voiceover): When he attended George H.W. Bush's funeral in late 2018, he was the oldest of America's living presidents. He celebrated his own 100th birthday in 2024. His beloved wife Rosalynn passed away in 2023. She'd been his steadfast partner through 77 years of marriage. Carter's diminished health prevented him from speaking at her memorial service so their daughter Amy, read a letter he wrote to Rosalynn while deployed with the Navy 75 years earlier. AMY CARTER, JIMMY CARTER'S DAUGHTER: My darling, every time I have ever been away from you, I have been thrilled when I returned to discover how wonderful you are. While I am away, I try to convince myself that you really are not, could not be as sweet and beautiful as I remember. But when I see you, I fall in love with you all over again. Does that seem strange to you? It doesn't to me. BLITZER (voiceover): Husband, statesman, a connection to an era now gone. Jimmy Carter was a defender of values forever current.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: Those who hunger for freedom, who thirst for human dignity, and who suffer for the sake of justice, they are the patriots of this cause. I believe with all my heart that America must always stand for these basic human rights at home and abroad. That is both our history and our destiny.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: When you were 10, what was he like when you first met him?

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: Just like he is now, just like he was all the time. Very honest, very straightforward and a very hard-working person and an intelligent person.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: When you were 10, what was he doing? What was he doing in the town?

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: How old was he in town? Goodness, I don't know. He just got out of the service when he came back.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Okay. So this is after his dad had died. So he was then working as a farmer, working on his dad's farm?

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: Yes, his. His business is right across from our drugstore. And I watched him unload peanuts from the back of a pickup truck onto a conveyor. So I got to watch him almost every day.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: You know, after serving in the White House, you know, he returned to Plains. He and Rosalynn lived in the same house. Most of their. What do you think it was about that place that was so part of them?

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: I think he felt like he was just part of the community and just like one of us. And like I said before, he didn't forget us. He worked very hard with our Better Home Committee to help develop a motel here, a hotel here, and. And also he's going to be buried here. And it's very deliberate move to keep people coming about to visit. On his part, even in death, he hadn't forgot the town.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: That was important to him, that Plains, Georgia, continue and thrive in the future.

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: That's right. Very important to him. It really was.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: He still. I mean, they attended the same church. He was still teaching Sunday school for a long time until he got until he got sick.

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: Got sick. He did. We enjoyed. We had several hundred people almost every Sunday come by to listen. And he took time after the church to take pictures with these people and just make them. Try to make them feel at ease and at home.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: What were his lessons like?

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: Very deep. I mean, he was old, too. It's almost like he was there.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: So he was talking from personal experience.

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's right. He made it very personal. He really did. I'm joking. But he made it feel seen real.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: What -- I mean, it's obviously, it's a sad day, obviously, but at the same time, I mean, 100 years old, and he spent 77 of those years with Rosalynn. What was your -- what are your memories of her?

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: Well, actually, she and I were kin. Her grandfather and my great-grandmother were brothers and sisters.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: No kidding. Wow. That's cool.

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: And she lived -- their home was not where I grew up, was about -- there's a house between us. And I wrote it, and she was older than I was, so I didn't get to see her too much, but I saw a sister and her brothers. In fact, her brothers were one of my teachers and my basketball coach. That family was part of my family, too.

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: I didn't know her. Her home was right next to ours. And I really enjoyed Ms. Lee. And she was a character. What came up, came out, and it didn't matter who you were and where you were.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: You said what? What came up, came out? I love that.

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: Right. If you didn't want to know the truth, you dare not ask her because she would tell you.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Wow. That's awesome. I actually met Jimmy Carter. My dad was from Mississippi and was a writer and got invited to Jimmy Carter's White House. And I got to meet Jimmy Carter's sister, who was an evangelist if I remember correctly.

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: Right, Ruth. I really didn't know her. I knew Gloria, his motorcycle sister, but I did not know. I didn't know the other lady.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I loved hearing about Jimmy. Motorcycle sister, whose tombstone actually says she's in Harley heaven, which I think is great.

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: Right, right. She was very much like Ms. Lillian, too. Very honest and straightforward. That wonderful lady.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, Boze, again, I'm sorry for your personal loss, but I really appreciate you taking the time to talk to us. I've really enjoyed it.

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: Well, I appreciate you calling very much. And I appreciate you doing the program for President Carter tonight. He was just a good friend, and I'm going to miss him tremendously.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Well, I know there's a lot of people. I'm sure everybody in Plains, Georgia feels that way right now and just --

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: And I'm sure. I'm sure. Right. Right.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Well, Boze, take care. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: GODWIN
utterances.sentences: All right. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Jimmy Carter worked for 40 years after he left the White House for peace and democracy around the world. Joining me is Stuart Eisenstadt, former U.S. Ambassador to the EU and President Carter's chief White House domestic policy adviser. He also wrote President CarterAmbassador, I appreciate you being with us. I'm sorry for the loss of your friend and the man you served. How do you think Jimmy Carter's leadership is going to be remembered around the world? Because I know in your book you have argued that he probably was one of the most consequential American presidents.

utterances.speaker: STUART EISENSTADT, FORMER CHIEF WF DOMESTIC POLICY ADVISER, CARTER ADMINISTRATION
utterances.sentences: That's right, Anderson. I mean everybody talks about his ex-presidency. A former president. Yes, he was a great former president. I believe that he was the most impactful one-term president that we've had in modern times. And the reason I say that is that all the ethics laws that we have in the books today are due to him. We have energy security because of his three energy bills which deregulated natural gas and oil, created the first renewable energy incentives solar panel on the White House. He was an environmentalist. He doubled the whole size of our national parks that Teddy Roosevelt had created by the Alaska Lands Bill. And he was a man who deregulated all transportation, airlines, democratized airlines, brought it to the middle class, trucking, rail, telecommunications.In fact there wouldn't be a CNN today had we not deregulated and allowed cable era to go. And he really enabled with telephone deregulation to start the whole era with cell phones and abroad, his remarkable. Human rights embedded in his foreign policy. It's the standard by which every other president is judged. He applied it to Latin America, and got thousands of political prisoners released and paved the way for the democracies that occurred during the Reagan administration. He applied hard power to the Soviet Union as well as soft power. Soft power was showing that it was a dictatorship and that we had a better form of government. He got twice the number of Soviet Jews out when he came in 50,000 a year. And hard power as well. Anderson, every single weapons system that Ronald Reagan gets credit for deploying and I applaud him for doing it. Every single one was started by President Carter. He normalized relations with China when Afghanistan was invaded by the Soviet Union. He took what even his conservative critics said was a tremendously tough stand. And so all of these are enduring. And the one that's the most remarkable, and I think it's the single greatest diplomatic achievement of any personal president in his activism, and that's Camp David. 13 days and nights, 22 drafts. And one thing that occurred that's really almost humorous now as we look back on it. The 13th day came, Anderson, no agreement. We were close, but no agreement. Prime Minister Bacon comes to Carter's cabinet. Camp David says, I won't make any more compromises. I want you to get me a limousine, take me to Andrews Air Force Base. I've got an all Al plane waiting. The President, realizing this would collapse Sadat's great initiative and would be egg on his face, knew that Begin had a great love for his eight grandchildren. He got his secretary to make eight copies of the original photo of the three leaders as they came personally inscribed it, walked it over to Begin's cabin, and saw his eyes tear and his lips quiver as he read the names of each of those grandchildren to Jimmy Carter with hopes for peace. He put down his bags and he said, Mr. President, I'll make one last try. And that's what did the job.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Wow, that's remarkable. What was behind the deregulation? I mean, often in history people will think, oh, well, he was very liberal. He wouldn't have been for such deregulation. What was the ideological idea behind it?

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Ambassador Stuart, that's fascinating. I appreciate your time tonight. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: EISENSTADT
utterances.sentences: Thank you for giving me.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to our breaking news this hour. The death of former President Jimmy Carter at the age of 100. He'd been in hospice care at home for nearly two years. But his passing surrounded by family in his hometown of Plains, Georgia prompts us to look back on his legacy and enduring mark that he left on this country and the world.Jimmy Carter met his wife of 77 years, Rosalynn, in Plains. He -- his mom actually delivered her. She was buried there two years ago. Jimmy Carter will presumably be laid to rest next to her, near her -- near their family home. Before his internment, there will be public observances in both Atlanta and Washington D.C. That schedule has yet to take shape, but it's expected to be a long period of remembrance with to 10 days worth of events. The impact of former President Carter's policies around the world have been felt long after he left the White House. CNN's Nick Robertson has more. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: I, Jimmy Carter, do solemnly swear.NICK ROBERTSON, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voiceover): Jimmy Carter's presidency lived in the shadow of America's Cold War with the Soviet Union. But he refused to be constrained by East-West Communist versus capitalist tensions.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: We expect that normalization will help to move us together toward a world of diversity and of peace.ROBERTSON (voiceover): He improved relations with China and tried for the same with the Soviets. In his foreign policies, he pushed for nuclear, non-proliferation, democratic values and human rights. He cut off military supplies to Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet and dialed back support for other Latin American leaders in Nicaragua, Argentina, and Brazil. One of his signature White House legacies was the Torre Carta treaties that returned the Panama Canal to Panama in 1999. He also calmed Mideast tensions, brought together Israeli and Arab leaders at Camp David, opening the door to the Israeli-Egypt Camp David accords. He normalized relations with China, weakened U.S. Ties to Taiwan in a vain hope Beijing would weaken ties with Moscow. But after the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan in December 1979, the last year of his presidency, he toughened his Soviet stance, backed the Afghan mujahideen in a war against the Red Army. The same year, 1979, Islamic Revolution in neighboring Iran dealt Carter a double domestic blow, spiked oil prices, and led to a humiliating failed raid, Operation eagle claw in April 1980 to rescue Americans captured by theocratic revolutionaries in Tehran.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: I can't stand here tonight and say it doesn't hurt.ROBERTSON (voiceover): Events overseas contributed to his 1980 election loss.

utterances.speaker: RICHARD HOLBROOKE, FORMER UNITED STATES AMBASSADOR TO THE UNITED NATIONS
utterances.sentences: We have work to do. We have to go back to it now. Thank you very much.ROBERTSON (voiceover): Less than a year later, another U.S. Diplomat, Richard Holbrook, parlayed Carter's brief calm into the war-ending Dayton Peace Accords. 1994 marked a peak in Carter's peacemaking, but far from the end of it, he helped found a group of seasoned international diplomats known as the Elders, whose works spanned the Mid-East and far beyond. He helped the charity, Habitat for Humanity, change lives, building affordable homes, often showing up to help with construction himself. In 2002, he was awarded a Nobel Peace Prize for decades of untiring effort to find peaceful solutions to international conflicts, to advance democracy and human rights, and to promote economic and social development. It was a path. He picked a post-presidency with meaning, and he followed it right up to his death. Nick Robertson, CNN, London. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: And joining me now is CNN senior political commentary David Axelrod. David, I'm going to read your own tweet back to you, but only because I think a lot of people appreciate the perspective you said. "In politics, many believe the worst epitaph is losers. Some are not strong enough to cope with defeat. Jimmy Carter lost an election and spent the rest of his life settling conflicts, conquering disease, and building homes for the homeless. He was in every way a winner.Talk about his life post-presidency and how that may define him.

utterances.speaker: DAVID AXELROD, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, Anderson, we've never seen anything quite like President Clinton, President Obama, President, but all the presidents since Carter have undertaken humanitarian missions through foundations and so on. But the scope and the span of Carter's activities, monitoring elections all over the world to protect democracy, negotiating in conflict zones, you know, eliminating the guinea worm in Africa, which was a persistent health problem in Africa. I mean, the scope of it is breathtaking. And the thing I think that is the through line here, both in his public office, years in public office, and out was his view of his purpose in life, which was service.He was as you know, all of these fascinating interviews you're doing are so great to listen to. And they underscore the fact that his principles were informed by his faith and he believed in the dignity of people, all people. And so he fought for civil rights, for human rights, and that became a cause that he continued to work on through the right up until his 90s. So, you know, just a remarkable life. And yes, I think, you know, in Washington you measure yourself or people measure you by wins and losses. And he suffered a brutal defeat in 1980. And I think he became sort of a pariah, frankly, for Democrats for a long time because of that, because he was identified as a loser. And we've seen more recent examples of people who categorize people by that way. We've seen a president who couldn't accept defeat not so long ago. So -- but he contemplated what he wanted to do with the rest of his life, and he decided that he was going to have the greatest impact he could possibly have and use the platform that the presidency had given him to make a difference. And he made a huge difference. And it's just so impressive.

utterances.speaker: AXELROD
utterances.sentences: Yes, listen, wherever he saw problems that were afflicting people and particularly people who were at a disadvantage all over the world, he tried to do what he could and had enormous impact. And, you know, I just so admirable. I was, you know, I think we should note Stu Eisenstadt's interview with you just a few minutes ago because Carter's presidency is undervalued. He, you know, was defined by two things, by inflation, largely as a result of the energy crisis that was exacerbated by the events in Iran and then the hostage crisis. But, you know, he was so ahead of his time. And the biggest thing, Anderson, was he was someone who brought a sense of ethics to office, Stu mentioned this. But remember, he followed the partial term at least of Richard Nixon. He resigned two and a half years before Carter took office.Gerald Ford did an admirable job, but he was connected to Nixon, having been his vice president. And along comes Jimmy Carter, a Sunday school teacher, a guy who was devout and who believed very much in ethics and truth and transparency and, you know, disclosed his tax returns, never been done before. Inspectors general, independent to oversee the federal government. And he challenged. He was an outsider who challenged the status quo, who challenged institutions, but challenged them for the purpose of trying to make them more responsive, not as a nihilistic kind of thing. So, you know, his presidency has been diminished in ways that are unfair, but his post presidency was something to behold.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: My name is Jimmy Carter, and I'm running for president.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: As the nation continues to mourn President Jimmy Carter, we're also looking back at his legacy that he left both during and after his time at the White House. Joining us now is CNN political analyst and historian, associate professor of history at Johns Hopkins University, Leah Wright Rigueur. Thanks so much for being with us.You know, I was talking to Ambassador Eisenstadt earlier about what he thinks is actually one of the most consequential presidencies in American history, which is Jimmy Carter's. Do you think people underestimate the things that Jimmy Carter accomplished as president?

utterances.speaker: LEAH WRIGHT RIGUEUR, CNN POLITICAL ANALYST AND HISTORIAN
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. And I think for a very long time there's been this understanding of the Carter presidency as either a failed presidency or when people are being generous, they'll say it was a mediocre presidency. But instead, I think particularly given that we are almost 50 years out from Jimmy Carter's presidency, we need to take a look at it with fresh eyes. We need to look at it both through the eyes of a man who is coming in with his faith at the centerpiece, who said, I don't want to force my religion on the American public, but I do want to bring a sense of humanity to the White House, that the sole goal of being in the White House should be to end the suffering of the American people.But then also that as we look at the issues that surrounded the moment that Carter was inflation, energy production, the foreign policy crises that beset the presidency and beset the world, that one of the things that emerged very clearly about the Carter presidency is that he attacked these with great verve and that had long term implications that we didn't even begin to see the consequences of, the positive consequences of for many years. And that it also wasn't just foreign policy, it also wasn't domestic policy, that there were any number of areas, but in particular around deregulation, that we should be looking at this and saying, wow, Jimmy Carter had an impact on America, on the world that rivals this kind of post presidency that we laud him for. Like we should actually be looking at this and say this is one of the best presidencies of the 20th century. And what does that actually mean for how we understand the modern American presidency?

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: The deregulation piece of this is interesting and it's not something I had really realized much before we, I was talking to Ambassador Eisenstadt about this just a short time ago. Deregulate -- regulation in the airline industry, which, you know, the ambassador was saying democratized airlines that, you know, made it much more accessible for people to be able to fly.

utterances.speaker: RIGUEUR
utterances.sentences: Yes. And in fact, Jimmy Carter is one of the reasons that we are able to fly and that people were able to fly across, you know, fly across the country, fly across the globe. But also taking a look at it and saying actually the airline industry shouldn't be as regulated in terms of travel, in terms of cost, in terms of price, there should be competition. It was part of this kind of, you know, I think we tend to think of deregulation as a conservative thing. Certainly the deregulation of Carter, of the quarter administration lays the groundwork for Ronald Reagan. But more importantly, what for Jimmy Carter what's about is there, are there unnecessary costs that we could get rid of that will open the country up for innovation, but also for democratizing things like travel.So this is what we see in the airline industry, but it's also what we see in the rail industry and in manufacturing and movement of goods and products.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: It's also just the context of when he became president, not just in the wake of Richard Nixon, the lies of Watergate, but also the Vietnam War.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Leah Wright Rigueur, I really appreciate your time tonight. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: RIGUEUR
utterances.sentences: Thanks for having me.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: We'll have more on our breaking news on the death of former President Jimmy Carter when we come back.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: Our social and political progress has been based one fundamental principle, the value and importance of the individual.Based on this knowledge of Georgians, north and south, rural and urban, liberal and conservative, I say to you, quite frankly, that the time for racial discrimination is over. These are not just my goals, and they will not be my accomplishments, but the affirmation of our nation's continuing moral strength. Human identity is no longer defined by what one does, but by what one owns. But we've discovered that owning things and consuming things does not satisfy our longing for meaning. War may sometimes be a necessary evil, but no matter how necessary, it is always evil, never a good. America did not invent human rights. In a very real sense, it's the other way around. Human rights invented America. (END VIDEOTAPE)
